content:
The Act may be cited as the "Non-Foreign Area Retirement Equity Assurance Act of 2008" or the "Non-Foreign AREA Act of 2008." It includes an extension of locality pay. The "Non-Foreign Area Retirement Equity Assurance Act of 2008" or the "Non-Foreign AREA Act of 2008" extends locality pay by including General Schedule positions in the United States and its territories within a pay locality. Amendments are made to allowances based on living costs and environmental conditions. The cost-of-living allowance rate is adjusted annually based on specific criteria outlined in the subsection. This section applies only to designated cost-of-living allowance areas as of December 31, 2008. Adjustments are made on the first day of the first pay period of each calendar year. The cost-of-living allowance rate is adjusted annually based on specific criteria outlined in the subsection. The term 'applicable locality-based comparability pay percentage' is defined for each calendar year. The adjusted allowance rate is computed by subtracting a percentage from the rate in effect on December 31, 2008, and dividing by a sum to ensure it is not less than zero. The cost-of-living allowance rate is adjusted annually based on specific criteria. The allowance rate computed must not be less than zero and is paid as a percentage of basic pay. SEC. 3. ADJUSTMENT OF SPECIAL RATES. Each special rate of pay established under specific sections of the United States Code in designated cost-of-living allowance areas shall be adjusted according to regulations set by the Director of the Office of Personnel Management or the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Temporary Adjustment - Regulations may allow for temporary increase in special rates during transition period ending on first day of first pay period after January 1, 2011, with excess pay converted to retained rate under section 5363 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. Transition schedule for locality-based comparability payments. In implementing the amendments made by this Act, the locality-based comparability adjustment rates for non-foreign areas under section 5941 of title 5, United States Code, shall be adjusted as follows: 
- In 2009, by using 1/3 of the locality pay percentage for the rest of the US locality pay area
- In 2010, by using 2/3 of the comparability payment approved by the President
- In 2011 and subsequent years, by using the full amount of the comparability payment. In 2011 and subsequent years, the full amount of the comparability payment approved by the President will be used for each non-foreign area. SEC. 5. SAVINGS PROVISION. The Act should not result in a decrease in an employee's pay. SEC. 6. APPLICATION TO OTHER ELIGIBLE EMPLOYEES. The term "covered employee" refers to an employee eligible for a cost-of-living allowance under title 5, United States Code, but not eligible for locality-based comparability payments. The Act defines a "covered employee" as someone eligible for a cost-of-living allowance under title 5, United States Code, but not eligible for locality-based comparability payments. This includes employees who become eligible for the allowance after the enactment of the Act and are not covered under specific sections of the Code. The Act defines a "covered employee" as someone eligible for a cost-of-living allowance under specific sections of the United States Code, including title 10, title 39, and title 5. This includes employees who become eligible for the allowance after the enactment of the Act. The Act defines a "covered employee" as someone eligible for a cost-of-living allowance under specific sections of the United States Code, including title 10, title 39, and title 5. This includes employees who become eligible for the allowance after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, covered employees may include those employed by the Transportation Security Administration of the Department of Homeland Security. The Act treats covered employees as regular employees under specific sections of title 5, United States Code, including pay fixed by statute and performance appraisal systems. The Act allows for the reduction of employee compensation based on performance. Additionally, postal service employees in nonforeign areas are affected by the amendment to Section 1005(b) of title 39, United States Code. Employees can elect additional basic pay for annuity computation. Employees who are separated from service by retirement under specific chapters of title 5, United States Code, between January 1, 2009, and December 31, 2011, can elect to be covered under this section by filing with the Office of Personnel Management. The computation of their annuity includes any cost-of-living allowance under section 5941 of title 5, United States Code. Employees separated from service by retirement between January 1, 2009, and December 31, 2011, can elect to be covered under section 5941 of title 5, United States Code. This section considers certain payments as basic pay for retirement purposes. Covered employees must pay into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Retirement Fund during the specified period. Employees separated from service between January 1, 2009, and December 31, 2011, can elect to be covered under section 5941 of title 5, United States Code. They must pay into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Retirement Fund based on certain payments considered as basic pay for retirement purposes. The employing agency of a covered employee shall also pay applicable agency contributions into the fund. The Office of Personnel Management may prescribe regulations for agency contributions based on employee payments, sourced from the same appropriation used to pay the employee. SEC. 8. ELECTION OF COVERAGE BY EMPLOYEES. Employees can make an irrevocable election under this section if they receive a specific allowance during a pay period when this Act is enacted. This applies to covered employees receiving allowances under certain sections of the United States Code. Employees described under subsection (a) have 60 days after the enactment of the Act to file an election with the Office of Personnel Management. They can choose to be treated according to the Act's provisions or as if the Act had not been enacted, with the cost-of-living allowance rate set at the 2008 level if no election is made. Failure to file will result in automatic treatment under subsection (b)(1). Employees under subsection (a) have 60 days to file an election with the Office of Personnel Management after the Act's enactment. The Office should provide timely notice of the election to employees. SEC. 9. REGULATIONS. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for implementing the Act, including rules for special rate employees, adjusting rates of basic pay for employees not entitled to locality-based comparability payments, and establishing and adjusting saved or retained rates for employees exceeding pay limitations. The Act imposes pay limitations effective January 1, 2011. The administrator of non-OPM pay systems must create regulations in line with OPM regulations. The Act, including its amendments, will take effect on the date of enactment. Specific provisions related to locality pay and schedule will be effective on the first day of the first pay period after January 1, 2009.
